title: Understanding and Predicting Personal Navigation
segmentation: Hello, it's me again so I'm going to talk about personal navigation an I don't mean how you get to a physical location, although we've done some work looking at physical locations, we're actually looking at how people navigate to content on the web and so we heard a little bit about this earlier this morning and I'm going to dive into it deeper now.
And this is work I did with Dan Liebling, an gayathrie Geetha from Microsoft.
So I'd like you to think about how you might get to the Microsoft Research homepage if you wanted to get there.
So how many of you know the URL and would type it in to get to the Microsoft Research homepage?
Couple of people would actually type it in.
How many people think it's in their history and would use it from there?
Try and pull it up from their history.
One person, two people.
How many of you have it bookmarked and will get to it via a bookmark?
No, we actually have a taker and how many of you would go to a search engine and enter a query for Microsoft Research?

Yeah, so this is this is the way that most of us get to these pages, particularly these pages that we just don't know the URLs off the top of our head and everybody who runs this query wants to get to the Microsoft Research homepage and it's listed 1st and we get to do all sorts of clever things with it too because we know that you want to go there so we can provide deep links.
We can provide kind of rich content to help you learn a little bit more about what that pages you know, so you can also think about.
Perhaps the wisdom homepage and how you might get that to that if you wanted to.
And I would guess chances are that we all want to search for it to get there.
But the problem is, the Wisdom homepage is actually not the 1st result for for the query wisdom, it's the 7th result and you know that makes it hard.
I actually often find myself reformulating my query 'cause it's below the fold and it's not really necessarily terrable that it's the 7th result.
Nick talked a little bit about this about how there's this diversity in some people who run this query are actually looking for.
This 1st result, probably most of the people who run this query.
There's a radio station called WS DM FM and it's located in Indiana, and that's probably what most people running the query want.
Also, not everybody who run this query necessarily want something that's informational, that's navigational.

Some people may have an informational intent, and this next one about web services distributed management going to Wikipedia page can help you learn a little bit more about the acronym Wisdom in a particular context.
And this next one actually is irrelevant.
This is a search engine screwing up and showing us last years page by accident.

Chris is going to talk more tomorrow about kind of temporal dynamics and queries, but you know, search engines aren't always perfect too, so sometimes sometimes they are going to get the wrong results for you.
You know we should be able to do better than this because you know what I run this query alot.
So how many people have used the query wisdom to get to find the Wisdom Home page?
And how many of you have done that only once?
Yeah, so that's pretty much nobody said.
We've all right, we got we got we got one but that's that's like a less than 1% of the people who have searched for this.
So we're running these queries over and over and over again.
And we know that repeat queries are really common on the web.
So 1/3 of all the queries that you issue are repeat queries.
And what's interesting is a really high portion of those queries that we issue over and over again.
Our navigational intent, where we're just clicking on the same result.

In response to that query, so it seems like we should really be able to take advantage of this, and this is this great opportunity for us to do something useful and low risk for personalization for at least the queries where we have the history about you and the question is how accurately can we make that prediction?
What kind of information do we need?
An you know how many queries are we going to impact the user experience for?
But we can guess just from looking at everybody's experience with the query wisdom here.
You can guess that it could actually have significant.
And then once we know what it is, we can move it up to the top and then also do all those other useful things that we talked about.
You know we can show deep links, we can show additional content.
We can even show the new content because these are pages that you've been to before and are revisiting again.
So we might be able to be like, oh, there's new content.
It says wisdom is going to be held in Seattle next year and you all should come and that sort of thing.

So the road map of my talk is I am first going to talk a little bit about general navigation and this is navigational behavior that we've identified based on aggregate user behavior based on how everybody is behaving.
This is what we kind of traditionally think of as a navigation, says everybody who's searching for Microsoft Research.
Once the Microsoft Research page 1st and then I'm going to talk.
There's that example, and then I'm going to talk about personal navigation, which is this instance where it's just you and your history that we're using to identify.
The navigational intent.
We're not using.

Everybody else is data, and we're going to talk about how we can identify personal navigation and we're going to compare the behavior with general navigation and look a little bit at the coverage and accuracy of the prediction and the consistency of the behavior overtime.
So how much history do I need of you to know that you're looking for wisdom?
And also does it change?
So if you look for wisdom last year and wanted WSD, MFM, the radio station, are you now going to want the conference when you when you run that query?

And then I'm going to talk about bridging the two behaviors and how we might be able to use both aggregate and individual data to do even a better job identifying this navigation behavior an all the analysis that I'm going to talk about is done using the Bing search logs.
It's based on millions of queries, millions of users.
You know, rich opportunity to look at this data.
So let's start looking at.
General navigation.
So we'd like to be able to identify general navigation.
It's good to start as we started thinking about navigation.

Actually, to think a little bit about just how common the behavior is in one of the best ways to do this is to ask people whether they're intending to navigate, and so Andrei Broder in his cigar forum paper where he introduced the concept of navigational behavior.
Did a survey where he popped up a browser and popped up in the middle of a query, a little window that said, are you intending to look for this particular for a particular website?
When you run this, and he found about 25%?
Of the queries people issue are navigational, so that's sort of a good target.
That's, you know it's a little old.
People are probably have a slightly different behavior now, but it's a.
It's a good, reasonable target of what we're looking for in want in identifying navigational behavior.
One way that people have gone about trying to identify navigation is using the querystring and so this is where you look for unambiguous query string.
So people have looked for queries that have URL fragments, or they've looked for queries that are company names and called those navigation.
You can find about 10% of queries you can identify as navigational in that way.
Of course, not all of them are always necessarily navigational.
Another one that we can use this click behavior and that was talked about this morning too.
Ingmar talked about using click entropy to identify navigational stuff and this is if people are clicking on all sorts of different things following a query, then it's probably not navigational.
But if everybody runs a query and clicks on exactly the same thing, then it probably is navigational.
And this is what we're going to do in our study.
The challenge here is you need lots of data, so you can't say after you've seen a query only 10 times.
Whether people are looking for the same thing or not.
'cause you just haven't had enough behavior to get an idea of that.
So you need lots of queries.

You need lots of different users running those queries, so if you have one query that's issued 1000 times but it's just me always searching for the same thing, I don't know that my intent is going to generalize to you, and you need lots of clicks following the query, so there are some queries that have lots of users and lots of instances, but they don't have a lot of clicks 'cause there tends to be the answer right in the page, so.
Weather is an example of that kind of query where people run the query for weather a lot, but then you're showing the weather directly in the page or dictionary.
Answers are dictionary queries or another one where you get the word defined in line.
So we use click behavior and using using these metrics where we wanted very low click entropy.
We wanted high high number of users and a lot of clicks.
We were able to identify 390 queries that are definitely navigational based on aggregate behavior.
And even though it's only a very few number of queries, it represents a significant portion of our query volume.
It's 300 and I mean it's 12% of our actual query volume and these are the queries that you might expect.
It's Facebook, it's YouTube, it's my space.
These are short queries.
They're about half the length of typical web queries.
They're easy to type there.
Generally one word.
They often contain a URL fragment, one out of every five.
You know, have.com or a WWW in them, and you know, as Nicholas said, these are the ones that perhaps personalization is not necessarily the most useful.
'cause we actually get it, right?
You know, the right result is listed as the first one.
Most of the time that people are looking for it.
So, however, there are actually some mistakes, despite these being really good, really high quality instances of navigation.
Sometimes there are problems.
So one thing that I think is sort of interesting is if you look at these queries so you know you look at your Facebook query and you try and say, well, how often does that click that?
Most people click on what the people click on, you find that that's only 72% of the time, so there's this whole other 28% of the time that people are clicking on something else.
And we also find that we miss a lot of queries that you would probably think or navigational.
You know, we miss things like Craigslist, or queries like weather.com and these are all queries that using the querystring you would have identified already as being navigational.
So what's going on?
Why did we miss Craigslist?

Well, the reason we missed Craigslist is because a lot of people are visit a lot of different things with Craigslist actually, so Craigslist returns the result for that kind of the California listings of things and sometimes.
And so a lot of you know, kind of the.
People searching from California go there and it returns.
Maybe the personal ads and the people interested in the personal ads might use that one.
People have lots of different intents, even though this seems like a navigational query.
Weather.com is another one that we miss, which is, which is strange.
And what's going on with weather.com is people aren't visiting things within it.
They're not going to like the 10 day forecast are, you know, they probably do that to some extent.
Visit things within it, but they're actually sometimes go to different results, so 17% of the results.
17% of the people who search for weather.com go to yahoo.com's weather page.
I just found this really interesting.
Actually, the most common click after the query realestate.com is realtor.com, which is a different website, so it's interesting that people do this.
They don't, even though you think it's obvious what people are looking for, it's not necessarily.
The case.
So that's a little bit about general navigation, and we've seen that we can do a good job of identifying these really high quality navigational queries in that way.
But that just because a query looks navigational doesn't mean it necessarily is.
And so now we're going to go on and talk a little bit about personal navigation where we're thinking about how we can use this repeat behavior to identify people's navigational behavior.
And I'm gonna talk about how we identify the navigation.
I'm going to compare that with general navigation and then look a little bit at some features.

So we've already talked some about how repeat queries are often navigational and and what's more, is there not just navigational, they used in long, long strings, and So what we do is, we say, OK, we will call a query.
We will predict that a query has a navigational intent.
If we look at a user's history and we see two examples of that query and they clicked on the same thing.
So here we've got this person who has the query wisdom and you can kind of go back into their history and you know here their history with kind of.
Let's say this is the first.

This is the most recent query and then these are older queries down here and you can say OK. Well they've issued wisdom before in the past, so we'll take the two most recent times that they've issued wisdom and will look at what they clicked on and we can see, Oh well, they clicked on the Wisdom homepage.
Then we can make that prediction and say we predict that that's what they're searching for.
And if they do something, if they clicked on something else and we're going to make that prediction, Ann will just say this is an instance where we don't.
We can't make a prediction and know what they're going to be doing.
So using this method we were able to make a prediction for a person, for for millions of unique queries.
So we could go find that you happen to like using the query banana to navigate to a particular site, and most of these are queries that don't occur very often.

So we found that most of them occur fewer than 25 times in the log, so a lot of these are just queries that you are sort of your own individual bookmarks, your own way that you search for things that maybe you know searches for.
Peoples Names Home pages that you don't go to that you know, not everybody else goes to and these queries are more ambiguous.
They don't contain URL fragments.
We saw 20% of the general navigation ones.
Did these pretty much none of them do, and they also have clicker click entropy.
That's about the same as as web queries in general.
So let's look at a few of these examples in.
Fire is an example of one of the personal navigation queries that we that we identified and what's happening here is.
This is an ambiguous query.

Some people use the query to refer to the National Enquirer, which is sort of a tabloid and American tabloid magazine, and some people use it to refer to the Cincinnati Enquirer, which is Cincinnati's local newspaper and so and so some people will use it for two different kinds of navigation.
Another thing you see is some queries are informational for a lot of people, and so here, bedbugs.
This one person is always going to this medicine net page on how to get rid of bed bugs.
But most people who are using bedbugs are kind of learning about bedbugs and doing other sorts of research on that.
What probably happened here with this person is that they were doing some research as well on bed bugs, and then they found this site that they liked and then they wanted to go back to it again.
And sort of along those lines.
You'll find these these serendipitous encounters too, so this is an example from me at C. Is this kind of handcraft website where you can buy hand crafts and when you search for?

When I was searching for Etsy once, I randomly saw this funny link to the site called Regretsy an it's a parody site of Etsy and I clicked on that and I didn't really remember the name for a long time and I had to use Etsy was the only way that I could get there.
So even though it seems that query that most people use for navigating to etsy.com, I happen to use it to navigate to something else.
So.
And and so because people are using these queries for many things, it's actually impossible for a general ranking of search results to show the 1st result first.
So there's this real opportunity here for us to be able to show different things to different people and think about how we can target it at particular people.

So in in for these kind of personal navigation queries that we identified the target of the navigation was less likely to be ranked first compared to general navigation, where it's almost always ranked first, but it was also less likely to be ranked first compared to just.

Search in general, which means that these are queries that actually often have results that are ranked lower, and then there's an opportunity for us to do something with ranking as well as with treatment and other other kinds of things.
Nonetheless, we found were able our predictions very accurate, so 95% of the time when we predict somebody is going to click on a result because it's a navigate personal navigation were right.
About it so we looked at how consistent our predictions were.
Overtime, we wanted to see how much history we needed, so we looked at using one month of user history.
So this is if you issue the query twice in one month, we can make a prediction.

We've looked at using smaller intervals, so we also looked at using just one week of your history to make the prediction and then we wanted to know a little bit about weather prediction could be done offline.
Whether we could or whether we had to be using your two most recent queries.
So we also looked at using one week of history, but then stopping and sort of doing the prediction going forward, assuming that we didn't have your real time.
History and then we also looked at using a week of history that was further back in the past.

So this is to think about where we might even think about doing some offline computation and say, oh you've done this query a couple of times, so maybe we'll go out and fetch deep links for this site and or, you know, do something to make it useful for you.

And what we found was that the accuracy is actually surprisingly consistent across the intervals of time that you use, so we're always having about a 95% accuracy when we start going a week back in history, you can see you see that accuracy drop a little, but.
We also find, but what we do find is that with time coverage drops, so this is sort of the further away that you get from your past, the less likely you are to still be using that query.
So so we're making accurate predictions when we make them, but we're just less likely to make predictions.
You're not running the same queries that you did a month ago necessarily.
So that's a little bit about personal navigation.

We found that re finding is often navigational, that people identify that we're able to identify unusual navigational queries, things that we wouldn't even think were navigational, like bed bugs, and that we have a high coverage and accuracy, and that the behavior is consistent overtime.
And I'm going to talk just a little bit about how we might be able to bridge these two things as well.
So some personal navigational queries are general navigation queries.
So we saw we had 12% of the of our query volume.
We could identify his general navigation 'cause these were the Facebook queries or the Twitter queries and then we saw that 15% of our of our volume we could identify as personal navigation.
This was wisdom or bedbugs, an obviously they overlap to some extent.
So about 5% are the same.
So we're where people are sometimes using Facebook in a personal navigation manner, and so we're identifying him.
In in that way.
But when you look at the accuracy of the prediction, you see that the personal navigation is a lot more accurate than what we were getting for the general navigation.
What's kind of interesting though, is in this little 5% in the middle, or actually super accurate we've got.
You know, this is where we're even more accurate.
Once we have that overlaps.
If everybody is using this query in the same way and you've used it for kind of personal navigation, then we can be pretty sure that it's like super super sure.
So I think there's a real opportunity here actually to start expanding.
And thinking a little bit about how we can capture more of this general navigation and some of the personal navigation as well.
So this is thinking about like, well, if everybody uses this.
A lot of people uses for navigation, but not enough that we're able to call it a general navigational query.
But you've done it once, and it looked like you were using it in that way.
Then we can start making those predictions, and we talked a little bit about ways that we look at using groups of data group data, so that's sort of the aggregate data.
You can also look at smaller groups, and we looked at IP address and how well we could do within.
Within an IP address and found that you can actually do pretty good and increase your coverage without hurting your accuracy too much.
So in summary, we've looked at a general navigation.
We have identified high quality common queries and seeing that things that look navigational aren't always things that people intend to be navigational, but that we can use.
Peoples refining behavior and peoples repeat search behavior to do a better job of thinking about what is actually navigational.

We've shown that we can get high coverage and high accuracy that this behavior is really consistent overtime, which I think is a is fun and that the general and personal navigation are complementary and probably can augment each other.
So we think this is a great opportunity for personalization that works.
It's sort of fun, safe thing to do.
And thank you.
